solution_04_inferential_statistics/01_T_dist/01_T_probs_v3

video

app

You can use a \(t\) table. Remember, the degree of freedom (df or \(\nu\)) is one less than \(n\). \[\text{df} = n-1 \]

Spreadsheet

You can use T.DIST and T.INV to calculate the values. But remember these functions return/use LEFT-area probabilities.

R

You can use pt and qt to calculate the values. But remember these functions return/use LEFT-area probabilities.


  1. When \(n=9\), then \(\text{df}=8\) and \(P(T<2.9)=0.99\).
  2. When \(n=38\), then \(\text{df}=37\) and \(P(T>1.69)=0.05\).
  3. When \(n=3\), then \(\text{df}=2\) and \(P(|T|<4.85)=0.96\).
  4. When \(n=30\), then \(\text{df}=29\) and \(P(|T|>2.15)=0.04\).
  5. When \(n=6\), then \(\text{df}=5\) and \(P(T<2.02)=0.95\), so \(t=2.02\).
  6. When \(n=38\), then \(\text{df}=37\) and \(P(T>2.03)=0.025\), so \(t=2.03\).
  7. When \(n=10\), then \(\text{df}=9\) and \(P(|T|<2.4)=0.96\), so \(t=2.4\).
  8. When \(n=10\), then \(\text{df}=9\) and \(P(|T|>1.83)=0.1\), so \(t=1.83\).
